body:
I think I see the problem here...

Rclone uses the [b2 copy file API](https://www.backblaze.com/b2/docs/b2_copy_file.html) to set the modification time (you can't change existing files on B2 even to set the modification time, you have to copy them).

That says

> Note that the resulting file must be less than 5GB. If you wish to create a file larger than 5GB, you must do it in parts with b2_copy_part.

So it looks like rclone should be using a different method for copying large files.

This is a reasonable amount of work unfortunately but we can follow a similar pattern as used in the s3 and swift backends.

Would you like to help with this?

Yes, of course! Tell me what I need to do.

~Doug
--
Doug Sampson
dsampson01 at gmail dot com


On Sat, Feb 22, 2020 at 2:47 AM Nick Craig-Wood <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> I think I see the problem here...
>

> modification time (you can't change existing files on B2 even to set the
> modification time, you have to copy them).
>
> That says

> Note that the resulting file must be less than 5GB. If you wish to create
> a file larger than 5GB, you must do it in parts with b2_copy_part.
>
> So it looks like rclone should be using a different method for copying
> large files.
>

> similar pattern as used in the s3 and swift backends.
>
> Would you like to help with this?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/3991?email_source=notifications&email_token=ABDW5IPAB7XVRYOAR53ZHA3RED7ERA5CNFSM4KZNBQIKYY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFVREXG43VMVBW63LNMVXHJKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOEMU5B5A#issuecomment-589943028>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABDW5IOPEL7LIDWKOFDJLS3RED7ERANCNFSM4KZNBQIA>
> .
>

> Yes, of course! Tell me what I need to do.

I had a quick look at this. The [mulipart copy](https://www.backblaze.com/b2/docs/large_files.html) is quite complicated, probably the best thing to do would be to parameterize the [multipart upload routine](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/backend/b2/upload.go) so it can call [b2_copy_part](https://www.backblaze.com/b2/docs/b2_copy_part.html) instead of `b2_upload_part`.

Then it is a question of factoring out the existing copy_file and calling the multipart copy if the size is >= 5GB (that is 5,000,000,000 - all the b2 docs use SI units).

I did the factoring out in 819bfe6211481ee10fccbf0ca67b0dca2358c1cd in the fix-3991-b2-modtime - I haven't got time to do the multipart copy stuff at the moment - can you help here?

I didn't realize what I was getting into when I said "yes". This is way
over my head.

Over the past weekend, I deleted the two files in our B2 cloud account and
reran the script. The uploads completed successfully. The subsequent runs
have not produced any error messages. I'm not sure what to make of this but
I am reasonably happy at the moment.

~Doug
--
Doug Sampson
dsampson01 at gmail dot com

over my head.

No worries! We'll get round to this eventually I'm sure!

> Over the past weekend, I deleted the two files in our B2 cloud account and reran the script. The uploads completed successfully. The subsequent runs have not produced any error messages. I'm not sure what to make of this but I am reasonably happy at the moment.

It is setting the modification time of an existing file that is the problem, so I'd expect deleting the files and re-uploading them to work fine.

rename.from: Failed to set modification time: Copy source too big
rename.to: b2: Failed to set modification time: Copy source too big

body: Is there any way to tell rclone not to use the B2 copy api and to re-upload the files instead?

> Is there any way to tell rclone not to use the B2 copy api and to re-upload the files instead?

Which command are you using @premeau ? If you want to disable server side copies then you can use `--disable Copy` - however I don't think that will disable the setting of the modification times using server side copy - that needs the b2 backend to return a special error when the modification time is set. This is possible to do with a flag I guess...

I am using sync .. and conducting a simple test, I have confirmed that `--disable Copy` is not tested during the modification time process.

Rather than continuing the discussion here, I'll open a separate issue and describe my situation and concerns.
@premeau I think you are experiencing the same issue most likely.

issue.title: Provide option to re-upload content to B2 rather than use file copy to adjust modification time.

milestone.title: Help Wanted

Any help doing these much appreciated.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is your current rclone version (output from `rclone version`)?

rclone v1.50.2
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.12.8


#### What problem are you are trying to solve?

Currently, rclone uses the `b2_copy_file` API call to update the metadata element containing the file's modification.

The current implementation appears to use the following process:
- `b2_list_file_names`  -- for the single file, to obtain the B2 fileId of the current version
- `b2_copy_file` -- to create a new version of the file with the same content but new metadata.

The issue is that both of these calls are Class "C" transactions in B2 -- the most expensive category.

Re-uploading the file would be "free" Class "A" transactions.  The "cost" would be upload bandwidth and time.

Currently, I can avoid the issue via `--no-update-modtime`, but run the risk of not updating content if the modification time changes but the size does not.   

Using `--checksum` ensures that content is updated and there is value in running a checksum based synchronization run occasionally to ensure the content is accurate, but it is an "expensive" operation 
if either the source or destination do not store a checksum in the metadata.

#### How do you think rclone should be changed to solve that?

I see several possibilities, and would defer to others regarding the best approach.

- Provide an option to disable all b2 copy operations.
- Provide an option to disable b2 copy operation only for modification updates.
- Provide an option to only use b2 copy if a file is above a minimum size, allowing the balance to be determined on a individual process basis.

Some of the options could assist with #3991

With freenas 11.3x rclone wont' even start the uploads.  I do have at least 50 5GB+ files which explains why this now fails.  Did Backblaze change something or did rclone change something?

rename.from: b2: Failed to set modification time: Copy source too big
rename.to: b2: Failed to set modification time: Copy source too big - need multipart copy

body: @Hescominsoon rclone should be able to upload files bigger than 5 GB fine, it is server side copying them which includes setting the modification time which is the problem.
[B2 just got an S3 compatible API](https://www.backblaze.com/blog/backblaze-b2-s3-compatible-api/). It’s still in beta, but would waiting for that to leave beta make this easier?

I just gave the B2 S3 compatible api a go - it works very well! You could use it to store data with rclone, however note that the method that rclone uses to store the modification time is different between the two so you can't swap between the methods.
